ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the history of German Youth and Student Movements from the 1800s to the present and improved my German tremendously while doing so.
Knowledge of the history of German youth groups as well as improved German proficiency.
Knowledge of German and ability to speak and write
The history of different student groups throughout German history and their impacts on society at the times they were in place and beyond.
Knowledge of multiple interesting German youth groups from the last 100 years, as well as cultural knowledge around the contexts for each of these
I learned about a lot of different German youth groups and movements and improved my German speaking and writing skills.
German grammar, speaking skills. I learned about the history of youth movements in Germany, especially during the Weimar Republic, WW2 and postwar era.
German of course and also a comprehensive century long history of youth movements
I this course I practiced my German skills. We covered vocabulary in topics related to student movements, while also working on grammar topics such as passive voice and Konjunktiv I.
I learned about German youth groups from the 19th century onward. I learned about a few more detailed grammatical concepts and continued to practice speaking and reading German.
Key insights into 19th and 20th-century German youth history

Learned about the history of youth movements in Germany across different time periods  Wandervogel, Hitler Youth, League of German Girls, Fridays for Future etc. Great topics across different historical time periods that kept the course interesting. Also worked a little on German grammar.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The main strength to this course is the professor, Professor Schenker. She is a wonderful, kind, engaging professor who always looks out for her students. I never was bored in class. Vocabulary, grammar, and content exercises in class were well organized and explained. Assignments were spread out through the semester to make sure we were never doing too much work at once, which I really appreciated. The course focuses on a very specific history, but in being in such a small niche we really got to learn a lot about the youth movements we were studying. Take it!
Its a great course!
Amazing course! No weaknesses

The course was very incredibly well organized and engaging. There was fantastic incorporation of sources from a variety of media sources, such as readings, videos, movies, etc. Classes were discussion-based and assignments were relevant to class material. No weaknesses!!

Strengths
- really engaging teacher and teaching style
- varied classroom and homework content
- inclusion of research into the class work

Weaknesses
- none

Strengths - great professor, diverse teaching materials, interesting subject matter 
Weaknesses - none
The course is IMMACULATELY designed and organized. It is designed to keep students constantly engaged, and while it can be a high workload at times, always is rewarding.

This course involved very interesting material and an aspect of German history which I knew close to little about. One aspect of this course that felt a little stressful was that there are frequent reading checks/deadlines/Flipgrid assignments.

The in-person language course is much better than the Zoom one; it was much easier to participate, as it felt like there was much less pressure whenever a student wanted to speak up (on Zoom, only one person can really speak in a room at a time, but in the in-person class it felt easier to have real conversations, or even answer a question in front of everyone, without the pressure of knowing that you were the focus on everyone's screen!). The reading was usually not too hard or too long, and the novel we read was engaging. The only thing I might change about the class is the percentage of the grade that is attributed to the final project; it is worth 30% of the class grade, which made it very stressful. It would be terrible to do well all semester and then get a sub-par grade in the class because of a few mistakes made on the final project, though I'd also like to say that I haven't seen this happen and it's possible that Professor Schenker accounts for this.
Could discuss the evolution (or lack thereof) of the German education system a bit more

Strengths:  Theresa is one of the best assets the German department and Yale itself have. This was such an interesting class where I learned so much and was never bored of the material. Assignments and expectations were always perfectly clear.
Weaknesses: Sometimes the workload was difficult to handle, but Theresa was always really accommodating and understanding. Anytime students expressed concern with how much reading there was to do, she would split it up for us and put us into groups. She would also, of her own volition, make assignments optional or cancel them during times like midterm weeks.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Take this and any other course you can with Professor Schenker. She's probably my favorite professor at Yale. This course is also extremely interesting and very relevant to us as college students.
Yes, I would definitely recommend it to students who want to improve their German.
Absolutely!

Yes! It was very interesting to learn about the subject matter and grammar lessons were incorporated seamlessly. The professor is also super engaging and makes the classroom environment very conducive to discussion and making mistakes and learning from them. I recommend!!
Yes, great way of expanding knowledge of German culture and learning about some interesting topics that are unique to this class but with contemporary relevance too
Definitely take this class! It was one of my favourite classes at Yale.
Yes! The course let me learn about a cool aspect of German culture in a welcoming and student-oriented environment.
Absolutely!
I would recommend any course that Prof. Schenker teaches; she is a professor who truly wants to see her students understand the material, and puts a lot of thought into lesson plans.

I would recommend it! Theresa is a great professor and she is very understanding and cares about student learning and student health. The course is interesting and reviews grammatical concepts throughout the semester without being too much work.
Absolutely take this course with Theresa. She is incredible, so understanding, and makes great syllabi that keep students engaged. Very fun and interesting class!
